revision.text:
{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} [[File:Lunch at DC Public Schools on 2012-10-09.jpg|thumb|250px|A school lunch in Washington, D.C.]] [[File:Nauru Secondary School Principal, Clarissa Jeremiah, inspecting school lunches, 13 November 2012. Photo- Rex Pirie, Australian adviser (12045528555).jpg|right|thumb|The principal of [[Nauru]] Secondary School inspecting school lunches (2012)]]
A '''school meal''' or '''school lunch''' (also known as '''hot lunch''', a '''school dinner''', or '''school breakfast''') is a meal provided to students and sometimes teachers at a school, typically in the middle or beginning of the school day. Countries all over the world have various kinds of '''school meal programs.''' Millions of children from all standards and grades get their meals at their respective schools every day. School meals provide high-energy food with high nutritional values either free, or at economical rates.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
The benefits of school meals vary from country to country. While in developed countries the school meal is a source of nutritious meals, in [[developing countries]] it is an incentive to send children to school and continue their education. In developing countries, school meals provide food security at times of crisis and help children to become healthy and productive adults, thus breaking the cycle of [[poverty]] and [[hunger]]. In all cases, school meals allow children to focus on their studies, without hunger as a distraction.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
==Types==
===Free school meal=== [[Sweden]], [[Finland]], [[Estonia]] and [[India]] are among the few countries which provide '''free school meals''' to all pupils in [[compulsory education]], regardless of their ability to pay.<ref name="18countries">{{Cite report |author1=Harper, Clare |author2=Wood, Lesley |author3=Mitchell, Claire|last-author-amp=yes |date=January 2008 |title=The Provision of School Food in 18 Countries |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/265032327_The_provision_of_school_food_in_18_countries |publisher=School Food Trust |page= |docket= |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote= }}</ref><ref name="Public Meal">{{cite journal |title=The Swedish School Meal as Public Meal: Collective Thinking, Actions, and Meal Patterns | url=http://uu.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:544062/FULLTEXT01 |journal=Digital Comprehensive Summaries of Uppsala Dissertations from the Faculty of Social Sciences |volume=80 |isbn=978-91-554-8431-6 |publisher=Acta Universitatis Upsaliensis Uppsala |year=2012 |pages=9{{ndash}}81}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wfp.org/school-meals |title=School Meals |date=2015 |website= |publisher=[[World Food Programme]] |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref> Many countries provide meals to improve attendance rates. In [[India]], where all the Government School students are provided with free lunch meals ([[Midday Meal Scheme]]), staple food that varies between different states and regions, is provided along with free education.
In high-income countries, free meals are usually available only to children who meet income-based criteria.
A study of a free school meal program in the United States found that providing free meals to elementary and middle school children in areas characterized by high food insecurity led to better school discipline among the students.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gordon|first=Nora E|last2=Ruffini|first2=Krista J|date=2018|title=School Nutrition and Student Discipline: Effects of Schoolwide Free Meals|url=http://www.nber.org/papers/w24986|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
===Reduced price meals=== '''Reduced price meals''' are also available in some countries to those who need a degree of assistance with costs. Lower-cost meals are available to students in such countries as [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Japan]], and the [[United States]].<ref name="18countries"/>
==Stigma== When they are not provided to all students, free school meals can [[social stigma|stigmatize]] children who do receive them. Studies have shown that many children entitled to free meals do not take them, and those who do may suffer negative consequences. Additionally, not all children who could benefit from free or reduced-price lunch qualify for it. Organizations such as the [[Child Poverty Action Group]] have called for school meals to be provided free of charge for all pupils to address these issues. In the United States, [[Share Our Strength]] has funded free-school-meal-to-all pilot programs in some [[school district]]s.<ref name="free_school_meals">{{cite web |url=https://www.nokidhungry.org/partners |title=Our Partners |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2009|website= |publisher=No Kid Hungry: Share Our Strength |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
==History== Growing rates of [[obesity]] in children have encouraged governments to provide healthier, more balanced school lunches.
For example, in the [[United Kingdom]], significant changes have been made from when school meals were introduced in the nineteenth century. The first National School Meals Policy was published across the United Kingdom in 1941. The Policy set the first nutritional guidelines for school lunches, requiring balanced meals which include the appropriate levels of [[protein]], fat, and [[calorie]]s.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal|last1=Evans|first1=C. E. L.|last2=Harper|first2=C. E.|title=A history and review of school meal standards in the UK|journal=Journal of Human Nutrition and Dietetics|date=April 2009|volume=22|issue=2|doi=10.1111/j.1365-277X.2008.00941.x}}</ref>
==Europe==
===Denmark=== School lunches in [[Denmark]] commonly include items like fruit, roasted [[duck]], potatoes, and red or white [[cabbage]].<ref name=huffingtonpost.com>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/09/school-lunches-from-aroun_n_2100142.html#slide=1739860 | work=Huffington Post | first=Emmeline | last=Zhao | title=School Lunches From Around the World | date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref>
===Estonia=== In Estonia, free school dinners are served in [[elementary school|elementary]] and [[secondary school]]s.<ref name="Public Meal"/>
====Nutritional guidelines==== <ref>{{cite web|title=Food-Based Dietary Guidelines {{ndash}} Estonia|url=http://www.fao.org/nutrition/education/food-based-dietary-guidelines/regions/countries/estonia/en/|website=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref>
===Finland=== [[image:finnish school lunch.jpg|thumb|A typical Finnish school lunch served free of charge to all pupils.]]
====History==== Finland provides free, catered hot school meals to all pupils from pre-primary to upper secondary education every school day, as guaranteed by the 1948 Basic Education Act.<ref name=investment>{{Cite report |author=Finnish National Board of Education |date=2008 |title=School Meals in Finland: Investment in Learning |url=http://www.oph.fi/download/47657_school_meals_in_finland.pdf |publisher=Finnish National Board of Education |page=1 |docket= |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote= }}</ref> Section 31 of the Basic Education Act states: "A pupil attending basic education shall be provided with a balanced and appropriately organized and supervised meal on every school day."<ref name=basiceducationact>{{cite web |url=http://www.finlex.fi/en/laki/kaannokset/1998/en19980628.pdf |title=Basic Education Act 628/1998: Amendments up to 1136/2010 {{ndash}} Section 31: Free education |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1948 |website=FINLEX Data Base |publisher=Finnish Ministry of Justice |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote= |pages=13{{ndash}}14}}</ref>
Some Finnish cities had offered poor students free school dinners since the beginning of the 20th century. For example, [[Kuopio]] did so starting in 1902, and extended school dinners to all students in 1945.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.koulut.kuopio.fi/Koulu125/1872/ka1872.htm |title=Koulun arkea: rangaistukset |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1997 |website=Paluu etusivulle |language=[[Finnish language|Finnish]] |publisher= |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=[https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.koulut.kuopio.fi%2FKoulu125%2F1872%2Fka1872.htm&edit-text=&act=url English translation from Google Translate]}}</ref>
====Current status==== According to Finnish National Board of Education statistics from the year 2014, the average school meal was valued at 2.80 [[euro]]s per student-school day, totaling 532 euros per student for the school year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vos.uta.fi/rap/kust/v14/k05z6yos.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509202345/http://vos.uta.fi/rap/kust/v14/k05z6yos.html |archivedate=9 May 2016 |title=Käyttökustannukset Opetuksenjärjestäjittäin (Euroa/Oppilas) Ilman Sairaala- Ja Vammaisopetusta |language=Finnish |author=Finnish National Board of Education |date=2015 |website=Opetushallitus |publisher=Finnish National Board of Education |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref> This sum included ingredients, labor costs, kitchen equipment, and other fixed expenses, but neither property costs nor taxes.
Children taking part in before- and [[after-school program|after-school activities]] are also served a free healthy snack.<ref name=":0">{{Cite report |author1=Lindqvist, Kai |author2=Hallakorpi, Antti |last-author-amp=yes |date=2008 |title=Kouluruokailusuositus: Valtion Ravitsemusneuvottelukanta 2008 |language=Finnish |url=http://www.ravitsemusneuvottelukunta.fi/attachments/vrn/kouluruokailu_2008_kevyt_nettiin.pdf |publisher=Valtion Ravitsemus-Neuvottelukunta |pages=1{{ndash}}14 |docket= |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote= }}</ref>
====Higher education==== Lunches for higher education students (like those attending universities and [[Institute of technology|polytechnics]]) are also [[subsidized]] in Finland. [[Kela (Finnish institution)|Kela]], the Social Insurance Institution of Finland, compensates student meals that fulfill the nutritional and pricing criteria for government meal subsidies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kela.fi/web/en/meal-subsidy?inheritRedirect=true |title=Meal Subsidy |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=|website=Kela |publisher=Kansaneläkelaltos {{ndash}} The Social Insurance Institution of Finland |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref> This program's purpose is to promote positive health and nutritional trends among students. The program accommodates special dietary needs – whether in connection with [[Religious dietary laws|religion]], [[food ethics|ethical beliefs]], or health issues – without extra costs.
====Objectives and role in learning==== Free school meals in Finland are viewed as an investment for the future; the aim is to maintain and improve children's health, well-being, and learning.<ref name=investment/> The school meal is used as a [[pedagogical]] tool for teaching table manners, food culture, nutrition, and healthy eating habits, as well as for increasing the consumption of vegetables, fruits and berries, wholemeal bread, and [[skimmed milk|skimmed]] or [[low-fat milk]].<ref>{{Cite report |author1=Fogelholm, Mikael |author2=Hakala, Paula |author3=Kara, Raija |date=2014 |title=Suomalaiset Ravitsemussuositukset 2014 |language=Finnish |url=http://www.ravitsemusneuvottelukunta.fi/files/attachments/fi/vrn/ravitsemussuositukset_2014_fi_web.pdf |publisher=Valtion Ravitsemus-Neuvottelukunta |pages=5{{ndash}}56 |docket= |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote= |display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ravitsemusneuvottelukunta.fi/portal/en/nutrition+recommendations/ |title=Finnish Nutrition Recommendations 2014 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=23 January 2014 |website=The National Nutrition Council |publisher=Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref> One of the basic lessons is cooperation between students, head teachers, teachers, parents, and catering staff. In many schools, students participate in the work of the school canteen during their [[:fi:Työelämään tutustuminen|working life practice period]]. Most schools have a school meal committee where students, teachers, and catering staff develop school catering together. Most schools also welcome parents to come and taste school meals. There are always adults present in the school restaurant. The pedagogical role of the school catering staff is seen as important, as is teachers' knowledge of nutrition. In 2009, Finland began developing school meal and nutrition education for teachers, and pedagogical education for school catering personnel.<ref>{{cite web|author=Peltonen, Maria |url=http://savotta.helsinki.fi/halvi/tiedotus/lehti.nsf/e1e392ad852e72f5c225680000404fa8/e0376a49e2de9744c225766c001fdf84?OpenDocument |title=HY: Kouluruokailun henkilökunnalla on myös kasvattajan rooli|publisher=University of Helsinki Communications Department |date=11 December 2009 |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=[http://savotta.helsinki.fi/halvi/tiedotus/lehti.nsf/e1e392ad852e72f5c225680000404fa8/e0376a49e2de9744c225766c001fdf84?OpenDocument English translation from Google Translate]}}</ref>
National and local regulations form the basis for Finnish school meal practices. Education acts and decrees<ref name=basiceducationact/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edilex.fi/smur/19980629 |title=The General Upper Secondary Schools Act (629/1998) |language=Finnish |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=21 August 1998 |website=EDILEX |publisher=Finnish Ministry of Education |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=[https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.edilex.fi%2Fsmur%2F19980629&edit-text=&act=url English translation from Google Translate]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.finlex.fi/fi/laki/ajantasa/1998/19980630 |title=The Vocational Education and Training Act (630/1998) |language=Finnish |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=21 August 1998 |website=FINLEX Data Base |publisher=Finnish Ministry of Justice |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=[https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.edilex.fi%2Fsmur%2F19980629&edit-text=&act=url English translation from Google Translate]}}</ref> and local curricula are central documents governing school meals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oph.fi/saadokset_ja_ohjeet/opetussuunnitelmien_ja_tutkintojen_perusteet/aamu_ja_iltapaivatoiminta|title=Aamu {{ndash}} ja iltapäivätoiminnan perusteet|date=2011|website=Opetushallitus Utbildningsstyrelsen|publisher=Opetushallitus Utbildningsstyrelsen|access-date=20 May 2016 |quote=[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=fi&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oph.fi%2Fsaadokset_ja_ohjeet%2Fopetussuunnitelmien_ja_tutkintojen_perusteet%2Faamu_ja_iltapaivatoiminta English translation from Google Translate]}}</ref> Local and school-level curricula define the central principles of arranging school catering. The curricula also describe the objectives for education in health, nutrition, and manners. The health-related and social role of school meals, the objectives of teaching nutrition and manners, and the recreational aspect of lunch breaks are taken into account when arranging school meals and snacks. Students are allowed at least 30 minutes for eating, after which they have a short recess outdoors.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
School lunches can also be a channel for empowering [[local food]] producers. Introducing locally produced fish to the offerings of institutional kitchens, such as school canteens, is an ethical and ecological alternative to mass-produced meat or imported fish.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.johnnurmisensaatio.fi/en/local-fish-swims-to-dinner-plates-in-turku/ |title=Local Fish Swims to Dinner Plates in Turku |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2 December 2015 |website=John Nurmisen Säätiö |publisher=John Nurminen Foundation |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
====Contents and nutritional guidelines==== School meals generally consist of [[Finnish cuisine|typical Finnish foods]]. A basic school meal consists of a warm main course, vegetables, bread, a table spread, and a drink.<ref>{{Cite report |author=Finnish National Board of Education |date=2014 |title=School Meals in Finland |url=http://oph.fi/download/155535_School_meals_in_finland.pdf |publisher=Finnish National Board of Education |pages=1{{ndash}}2 |docket= |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote= }}</ref> The school lunch is calculated to equate to about one-third of a child’s daily nutritional needs. School catering is designed to follow the National Nutrition Council's dietary guidelines for schools.<ref name=":0"/> The recommendations for school meals are being updated during the year 2016.
Normally, Finnish schools provide lunch at school canteens in the form of a [[buffet]], where pupils serve themselves as much as they want. Schools often use a model plate to guide eating habits towards the following recommendations:{{efn|See, for example, [http://www.hel.fi/www/helsinki/en/day-care-education/kouluruokalistat this list of sample school menus] from the city of Helsinki.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hel.fi/www/helsinki/en/day-care-education/kouluruokalistat |title=School Menus |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=8 January 2016 |website=Daycare and Education |publisher=City of Helsinki |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>}}<ref name=":0"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ravitsemusneuvottelukunta.fi/files/attachments/fi/vrn/juomat_lapsi_en_high.pdf |title=Children and Young Persons: You Need 1 {{ndash}} 1.5 Litres of Liquids Daily in Addition to Food |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= |publisher=Valtion Ravitsemusneuvottelukunta |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref> * Fresh and cooked vegetables covering half of the plate * Potatoes, rice, or pasta covering one quarter of the plate * Fish at least once a week (preferably twice a week); meat; or beans and sprouts as part of a vegetarian diet covering the remaining quarter of the plate * Skimmed or semi-skimmed milk, or [[fermented milk products]] * Water * Bread with vegetable margarine or a butter-margarine blend * Berries or fruit for dessert
Children with special dietary needs – whether in connection with religion, ethical beliefs or health issues – are entitled to a special diet without costs. School menus are designed to be suitable for most students, with minor adjustments if needed. If a child has special dietary needs, their school requires specific information about those needs to ensure [[food safety]] and the elimination of possible [[cross contamination]]. In the case of health-related special diets, schools require the assessment of a doctor, nurse, or [[dietitian]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oph.fi/koulutus_ja_tutkinnot/perusopetus/hyvinvointi_ja_turvallisuus/kouluruokailu/kotivaki/erityisruokavaliot|title=Opetushallitus - Erityisruokavaliot|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016 |language=Finnish |quote=[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=fi&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oph.fi%2Fkoulutus_ja_tutkinnot%2Fperusopetus%2Fhyvinvointi_ja_turvallisuus%2Fkouluruokailu%2Fkotivaki%2Ferityisruokavaliot English translation from Google Translate]}}</ref>
As with school lunches, before- and after-school snacks are used as a pedagogical tool in teaching children about proper nutrition, table manners, and food culture. Snacks are designed to offer variety and take into consideration Finnish Nutrition Recommendations as well as children’s individual needs.<ref name=":0"/>
====The School Lunch Diploma==== Finland has no national [[accreditation]] system to evaluate the quality of school lunches. However, by the end of 2015, over 200 schools had been awarded the School Lunch Diploma.<ref name=diploma>{{cite web |url=http://www.kouluruokadiplomi.fi/schoollunchdiploma/ |title=The School Lunch Diploma |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=|website=Kouluruoka Diplomi |publisher= |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref> The diploma certifies a school's commitment to the national standards and recommendations for nutritionally, educationally, and ecologically [[sustainability|sustainable]] school lunches.<ref name=diploma/> It is also an indication of excellent collaboration among interest groups within the school. The School Lunch Diploma is coordinated by the Finnish Kitchen Professionals Association.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
===France=== ====History==== In the 1970s, the [[Government of France|French government]] began to work on improving school lunches. In 1971, the government established nutritional guidelines for French school meals. The 1971 food recommendation guidelines stated that each meal should contain raw vegetables, such as salads and fruits; protein in the form of milk or other dairy products; cooked vegetables twice per week; and carbohydrates on the remaining days.<ref name="theguardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2005/mar/30/schoolmeals.schools1|title=School Meals Around the World|work=The Guardian|date=30 March 2005|accessdate=20 May 2016|location=London}}</ref>
====Current status==== In France, lunch is considered the most important meal of the day. Students can get lunch at school or go home for it. The lunch break is one to two hours long. French students are taught to take time to savor and enjoy their meals.<ref name="theage"/> Students have to pay for cafeteria lunches; the cost of the meal varies by region. A student's family pays for half of the meal, while the school pays for the remainder. For example, a typical meal may cost $6, with the family paying $3 instead of the full price.<ref name="theguardian"/>
====Contents and nutritional guidelines==== The 2001 food recommendation guidelines, signed by the Minister for National Education, state that school lunches must be healthy and balanced. Menus vary daily, and are posted for parents. Specifically, the guidelines state that:<ref name="theage">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/restaurants-and-bars/sandwiches-mais-non-20100216-o82i.html |author=Santich, Barbara |title=Sandwiches, Mais Non |work=The Age |date=17 November 2009 |accessdate=20 May 2016 |location=Melbourne, Australia |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120815062740/http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/restaurants-and-bars/sandwiches-mais-non-20100216-o82i.html |archivedate=15 August 2012 |publisher=Fairfax Media }}</ref> * There should be very little fat in school foods * School meals must contain [[vitamin]]s and [[Dietary element|minerals]] * The main course of each school meal must contain meat, fish, or eggs
School cafeterias serve five-course meals, even for preschoolers.<ref name="timemagazine">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1967060,00.html|title=Teaching Kids to Eat Healthy: School Lunches in France |work=[[Time (magazine)|''TIME'']] |date=23 February 2010| author=Walt, Vivienne |accessdate=20 May 2016 |publisher=Time, Inc.}}</ref> Schoolchildren eat the same things as adults.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kitchendaily.com/2010/02/22/school-lunches-around-the-world/|title=School Lunches Around the World|work=Kitchen Daily|date=22 February 2010 |accessdate=20 May 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827155951/http://www.kitchendaily.com/2010/02/22/school-lunches-around-the-world/ |archivedate=27 August 2010 |author=Stern, Steven |publisher=AOL Inc.}}</ref> A school lunch in France contains an [[appetizer]], [[salad]], [[main course]], [[cheese plate]], and dessert.<ref name="timemagazine"/> Bread may accompany each meal. A menu might include [[potato]] [[leek]] [[soup]], [[carrot]] and [[bean]] [[salad]], [[lamb and mutton|lamb]] with [[saffron]], an assortment of cheeses, and [[grapefruit]]. Each meal is accompanied with water.<ref name=france/>
French schools do not have [[vending machine]]s.<ref name=france>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/4298245.stm |title=School Dinners Around the World|work=BBC News Online |publisher=BBC|date=12 March 2005|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref>
===Italy=== School meals in [[Italy]] provide regular [[Italian cuisine]], although they may vary among regions and towns. The [[Government of Italy|Italian government]] is very "down to people" and is doing a large-scale study to measure and involve students in food habits, diets, and food choices.<ref name="A Table of Colors">{{cite web| url=http://dietne.com/a-table-of-colors/ | title=A Table of Colors | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160326095254/http://dietne.com/a-table-of-colors/ |archivedate=26 March 2016| date=4 November 2015 |accessdate=20 May 2016 |publisher=Dietne: Diet Nutrition and Education}}</ref>
===Norway=== Norwegian school lunches were supplied from Sweden during [[World War II]], partly privately financed. Later, all public school lunches were discontinued, so most Norwegian students bring a packed lunch from home. In 2007, schools began providing one free piece of fruit each day for all pupils in grades 8–10. Norwegian schools also sell subsidized milk.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
===Sweden=== School lunches have been free in [[Sweden|Swedish]] elementary schools since 1973.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Cross, Maria |author2=MacDonald, Barbara |last-author-amp=yes |date=26 January 2009 |title=Nutrition in Institutions |url= |location= |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |page=86 |isbn=978-1444301670}}</ref> The government or [[municipality]] covers all charges. Normally, school lunches are buffet-style. Buffets chiefly include potatoes, pasta or rice; meat or fish; and vegetables. Milk and water are usually offered as drinks.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There are also vegetarian options, as well as foods that meet religious requirements; these foods are also free of charge. Upper secondary schools do not have to provide meals for their students, but many, both public and charter schools do.<ref>{{cite web |accessdate=23 Jan 2018| title=Mat i förskolan och skolan |url=https://www.skolverket.se/regelverk/mer-om-skolans-ansvar/mat-i-skolan-1.185012| language=[[Swedish language|Swedish]]}}</ref>
Usually, each municipality signs a private contract with a catering company which provides school food. Many of the food products are imported, but still have a good standard. In many schools, teachers or the [[school principal]] eat with the pupils, with the goal of creating a stronger connection between students and school authorities.<ref name="official food info">{{cite web |url=http://www.skolmatsverige.se/skolmaltidens-kvalitet-lasaret-201213 |title=Skolmåltidens kvalitet läsåret 2012/13 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2013 |website= |publisher=SkolmatSverige |accessdate=20 May 2016 |language=[[Swedish language|Swedish]] |quote=[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=sv&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.skolmatsverige.se%2Fskolmaltidens-kvalitet-lasaret-201213 English translation from Google Translate]}}</ref> In Swedish schools there are also international food weeks, or vegetarian weeks.
===United Kingdom=== ====History==== School meal programs in the United Kingdom can be traced back to the [[Education (Provision of Meals) Act 1906]].
In 1944, the United Kingdom required local authorities to provide school dinners that were consistent with legal nutritional requirements. The government paid the full cost of school meals in 1947.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> Free school meals were available to children with families on very low incomes.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writers--> |title=Jamie's School Dinners |url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/jamies-school-dinners |newspaper=Channel 4 |location=London |date= |accessdate=20 May 2016 |publisher=Channel 4 Television Corporation}}</ref> As a result, from the 1950s onward, staple traditional "school dinner" foods became embedded in the national psyche. "School [[pudding]]s" in particular refers to desserts historically served with school dinners in state and private schools. Examples include tarts such as [[gypsy tart]] and [[Manchester tart]], and hot puddings such as [[spotted dick]] and [[treacle sponge pudding]].{{efn|British [[celebrity chef]] [[Gordon Ramsay]] discusses school puddings as [[comfort food]] in ''The Times''.<ref>{{cite news |author=Ramsay, Gordon |title=Food and Drink: Gordon Ramsay <!--Created default title {{ndash}} article is behind paywall --> |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/food_and_drink/gordon_ramsay/article1304892.ece |newspaper=The Times Online |location=London |date= |accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref>}}
In the 1980s, [[Margaret Thatcher]]'s [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] government ended entitlement to free meals for thousands of children, and obliged local authorities to open up provision of school meals to competitive tender. This was intended to reduce the cost of school meals provided by local authorities. However, it caused a substantial decrease in the standard of school food.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} A 1999 survey by the [[Medical Research Council (UK)|Medical Research Council]] suggested that despite [[Rationing in the United Kingdom|rationing]], children in 1950 had healthier diets than their counterparts in the 1990s, with more [[nutrient]]s and less fat and sugar.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.educationengland.org.uk/articles/22food.html |title=Food for Thought: Child Nutrition, the School Dinner and the Food Industry |author=Gillard, Derek |date=June 2003 |website= |publisher= Education in England: The History of Our Schools |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
This became a major topic of [[debate]] in 2004, when [[chef]] [[Jamie Oliver]] spearheaded a campaign to improve the quality of school meals. At this time, school dinners at state schools were normally made by outside caterers. The schools sold a lot of deep-fried [[fast food]], like chips, fried turkey nuggets, pizza, and pies. After the "Jamie's School Dinners" programme was shown on [[Channel 4]], sections of the public showed support for increased school meal funding, causing the government to create the [[School Food Trust]]. This topic became a factor in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 UK general election]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Campbell|first1=Denis|title=How to save school dinners – part two|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/oct/24/jamie-oliver-fight-healthy-eating-schools|website=The Guardian|accessdate=21 November 2017|date=24 October 2011}}</ref>
Martha Payne's [[blog]] [[NeverSeconds]], which discussed the quality of school meals at her primary school in Lochgilphead, made national headlines after gaining support from Jamie Oliver.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsround/18036473|title=Argyll girl's school lunch blog NeverSeconds is web hit|publisher=CBBC Newsround|date=15 May 2012|accessdate=15 June 2012}}</ref>
====Current status==== Since September 2014, all infant pupils in [[England]]'s schools have been entitled to a free hot meal at lunchtime every day. This was an initiative of [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Nick Clegg]], who launched the plan at the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] conference in 2013. At the initiative's inception, the government was paying £2.30 for each meal taken by newly eligible pupils.<ref name=infants/>
The [[Government of the United Kingdom|British government]] uses entitlement to free school meals as a measure of deprivation. For the financial year 2014-2015, the government paid schools a premium of £1,300 for primary-aged pupils, or £935 for secondary-aged pupils, for each eligible child. 11% of families entitled to free meals do not claim them, which means that their schools do not receive the extra funding. It was unclear in 2014 how this would be affected by the introduction of universal free meals for the youngest British schoolchildren.<ref>{{cite news |author=Coughlan, Sean |title=Free School Meals Threat to Poor Pupil Funds, Say Heads |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/education-26665336 |newspaper=BBC News Online |location= |date=20 March 2014 |accessdate=20 May 2016 }}</ref>
Since January 2015, the [[Government of Scotland|Scottish government]] has provided free school meals for all children in Primary One to Three.<ref name=infants>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer--> |title=Q&A: Free School Meals for Infants |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/education-28981684 |newspaper=BBC News Online |location= |date=2 September 2014 |accessdate=20 May 2016 }}</ref>
====Advocacy==== The [[National Union of Teachers]] supports free school meals for all children. [[Fiona Twycross]] campaigned to persuade the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] to commit to providing universal free school meals. She argues that according to the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] and the [[National Centre for Social Research]], free school meals for all students significantly increases attainment in schools.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sochealth.co.uk/2013/06/26/why-free-school-meals-for-all/ |title=Why Free School Meals for All? |author=Twycross, Fiona |date=26 June 2013 |website= |publisher=Socialist Health Association |accessdate=20 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
==Asia== ===China=== {{expand section|date=October 2012}} A typical school lunch in [[the People's Republic of China]] includes [[staple food]], [[Meat|meat diet]], [[Vegetable|vegetable dish]], and each school has different kind of dishes. Students can choose between two and three dishes according to their preferences, with a staple food, usually [[rice]].
===India=== {{Main|Midday Meal Scheme}} ====History==== The roots of India's school meal programme can be traced back to the pre-independence era, when a mid day meal programme was introduced in 1925 in [[Madras Corporation]] by the British administration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mdm.nic.in/aboutus.html |title=About the Mid Day Meal Scheme |publisher=Mdm.nic.in |date= |accessdate=28 July 2013}}</ref>. This was one of the oldest free food programmes for schoolchildren. In 1975, the [[Government of India|Indian government]] created the [[Integrated Child Development Services]] (ICDS) programme. Under the [[Midday Meal Scheme]], government high schools and partially aided schools, along with [[Anganwadi]]s, provide midday meals to students. The meals are free of cost and meet guidelines that have been set by policy.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
By 1998, India had deployed the National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education (NP-NSPE) scheme. During the 2013-2014 school year, the scheme covered 104 million children in 1.16 million schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mdm.nic.in/aboutus.html |title=About the Indian Mid Day Meal Scheme |website=Mid Day Meal Scheme |publisher=Ministry of Human Resource Development, Department of School Education & Literacy, Government of India |accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
The [[Akshaya Patra Foundation]], a public-private partnership in the Midday Meal Program, is a school meal program run by a [[non-governmental organization]]. Akshaya Patra started serving 1,500 children in the year 2000. Today it serves lunch to over 1.4 million school children in 10 [[States of India|Indian states]] every day.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.akshayapatra.org/indias-mid-day-meal-scheme |title=Mid-Day Meal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=|website=Akshaya Patra: Unlimited Food for Education |publisher=Akshaya Patra Foundation |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
====Contents==== A single afternoon lunch usually contains a [[cereal]] which is locally available, made in a way that conforms to prevailing local customs. Each child receives milk, and either soup or vegetables cooked as [[curry]]. The menu is occasionally varied to appeal to students.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
Children in private schools usually carry their own [[lunch box]]es. Many schools also have canteens, and street food vendors can often be found in front of school campuses.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
===Indonesia=== Being a developing country, government schools in Indonesia fail to provide students with lunch meals. Rather, students would buy street food, also known as ''gorengan'', or bring a packed lunch from home. A typical school lunch would include rice, meatball soup, tofu, and vegetables<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/school-lunches-around-the-world-2014-5#jakarta-indonesia-rice-meatball-soup-tofu-and-vegetables-12|title=Here's What School Lunch Looks Like In 13 Countries Around The World|last=Penn|first=Alyson|date=2014-05-08|work=Business Insider Australia|access-date=2018-08-21|language=en}}</ref>. More fortunate students enrolled in private schools have the advantage of having lunch served to them or a fully packed canteen with different stalls where they could buy food during break time.
=== Iran === In the 1960s, Shah [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]] had intended a [[non-violent]] regeneration of [[Iran]]ian society through economic and social [[Reform movement|reforms]] called the [[White Revolution]]. The reforms' long-term goal was to transform Iran into a global economic and industrial power. The White Revolution consisted of 19 elements that were introduced over a period of 15 years. In 1975, the Shah started a program for 'Free and Compulsory Education and a daily free meal' for all children from [[kindergarten]] to 14 years of age. It provided one-third of a [[pint]] of free milk to all children in Iran, as well as [[pistachio]]s, fresh fruit, and biscuits.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
===Japan=== ====History==== In [[Japan]], the tradition of providing school lunches started in the early 20th century. After [[World War II]], which brought near-[[famine]] conditions to the country, the [[Government of Japan|Japanese government]] re-introduced school lunches in urban areas. School lunch was extended to all elementary schools in Japan in 1952. With the enactment of the School Lunch Law in 1954, school meals were extended to [[junior high schools]] as well.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
These early lunches initially included items such as bread, bread rolls, and [[powdered milk|skimmed milk powder]] (replaced in 1958 by milk bottles and cartons). Later, lunches were expanded to include [[flour]] donated by an American [[charitable organization|charity]]; a dessert; and a dish (such as [[daikon]]) that changed daily.<ref name=washingtonpost.com>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/on-japans-school-lunch-menu-a-healthy-meal-made-from-scratch/2013/01/26/5f31d208-63a2-11e2-85f5-a8a9228e55e7_story.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Chico | last=Harlan | title=On Japan's school lunch menu: A healthy meal, made from scratch | date=30 January 2013 |accessdate=21 May 2016 |publisher=WP Company LLC}}</ref> Other dishes included inexpensive protein such as stewed bean dishes, fried white [[fish]], and, until the 1970s, [[whale meat]]. Provisions of [[rice]] were introduced in 1976, following a [[Excess supply|surplus]] of government-distributed Japanese rice, and became increasingly frequent during the 1980s. [[Hamburg steak]], [[stew]] and [[Japanese curry]] became staples as well.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
====Current status==== As of 2004, 99% of [[Elementary schools in Japan|elementary school]] students and 82% of [[junior high school]] students in Japan ate ''kyūshoku'' (school lunch).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mext.go.jp/b_menu/toukei/001/index24a.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041205044027/http://www.mext.go.jp/b_menu/toukei/001/index24a.htm |archivedate=5 December 2004 |title=学校給食実施状況調査 |language=[[Japanese language|Japanese]] |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= |publisher=Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science, and Technology |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=ja&tl=en&u=https%3A%2F%2Fweb.archive.org%2Fweb%2F20041205044027%2Fhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.mext.go.jp%2Fb_menu%2Ftoukei%2F001%2Findex24a.htm English translation from Google Translate]}}</ref> The food is grown locally, is almost never frozen, and (barring dietary restrictions) is the same for every student.<ref name=washingtonpost.com/> Children in most districts cannot bring their own meals to school until they reach high school, nor do schools have vending machines; instead, children are taught to eat what they are served.<ref name=washingtonpost.com/>
In both elementary school and [[middle school]], students put on white coats and caps and serve their classmates, who then all eat together in their classrooms instead of in a cafeteria.<ref name=washingtonpost.com/>
To make lunches affordable for students, municipalities pay for the labor costs, while parents, who are billed monthly, pay for the ingredients.<ref name=washingtonpost.com/> These typically cost about 250 to 300 [[Japanese yen|yen]] (about USD $3) per meal per student. There are reduced-price and free options for poorer families.<ref name=washingtonpost.com/>
====Contents and nutritional guidelines==== The daily [[bento]] boxes are designed by [[nutritionist]]s to provide a balanced yet tasty meal for schoolchildren, working especially to appeal to picky or unhealthy eaters.<ref name=washingtonpost.com/> According to Chico Harlan:<ref name=washingtonpost.com/>
{{Quote |Though Japan's central government sets basic nutritional guidelines, regulation is surprisingly minimal. Not every meal has to meet precise caloric guidelines......Central government officials say they have ultimate authority to step in if schools are serving unhealthy food, but they can’t think of any examples where that actually happened. ... And because this is food-obsessed Japan, those standard meals are restaurant-worthy; in fact, [[Adachi, Tokyo|Adachi Ward]] publishes a full-color cookbook based on its best school meals. [However,] [[Japanese cuisine]] isn't automatically healthy; it includes crispy chicken, rich bowls of salty [[ramen]] with [[pork belly]] and battered and deep-fried [[tempura]]. But, like most cuisines, it can be healthy. ... You don't see dessert, other than fruit and yogurt. You occasionally see fried food, but in stark moderation. }}
Common dishes range from [[Asian cuisine|Asian]] [[Korean noodles|myeon]], [[tom yam]], and [[ma po tofu]], to Western foods such as [[spaghetti]], [[stew]], and [[clam chowder]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
[[File:SchoolLunch KyushokuToban.jpg|thumb|In Japan, students set and clean the tables]]
===Malaysia=== In most [[Malaysia]]n schools, regardless of whether they are public or private schools, students eat in a canteen where they purchase food and drinks from vendors. School canteens usually offer [[Malay cuisine|Malay]], [[Chinese Cuisine|Chinese]], and [[Indian Cuisine|Indian]] foods, with varieties of rice, noodles, and breads. The average Malaysian school canteen offers varieties of [[Nasi Lemak]], [[Nasi Goreng]], [[Hainanese Chicken Rice|Chicken Rice]], [[Popiah]], and [[Laksa]].<ref name=malaysia/>
School canteens sell food and drinks at reduced prices. Underprivileged students can apply for the free-food program {{ndash}} which, depending on the school, is either sponsored by the school's [[parent-teacher association]] or by the [[Ministry of Education (Malaysia)|Ministry of Education]].<ref name=malaysia>{{cite web |url=http://www.moe.gov.my/en/rmt |title=Supplementary Food Programme |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=24 December 2012 |website= |publisher=Ministry of Education of Malaysia |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref> Low-income students may also be eligible for the School Milk Program, which is funded by milk companies and [[non-governmental organization]]s.<ref name=malaysiamilk>{{cite web |url=http://www.moe.gov.my/en/pss |title=The Schools Milk Programme (SMP) |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=24 December 2012 |website= |publisher=Ministry of Education of Malaysia |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
===The Philippines=== School meals in the Philippines appear to be relatively simplistic, consisting mainly of rice, meat, and [[gravy]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===Singapore=== School meals in most [[Singapore]]an primary and secondary schools, as well as [[junior college]]s, are provided in each school's canteen (or tuckshop). The canteens consist of stalls which sell a variety of foods as well as beverages. To cater to the many races, religions, and cultures in Singapore, canteens often offer a range of cuisines, like Chinese, Indian, Malay, and Western foods.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hpb.gov.sg/HOPPortal/content/conn/HOPUCM/path/Contribution%20Folders/uploadedFiles/Schools/Healthy_Meals_in_Schools/HMSP_criteria_2016.pdf |title=Healthy Meals in Schools Programme Criteria 2016 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=|website=Healthy Meals in School Programme |publisher=Government of Singapore |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
To encourage healthier eating habits among children, the [[Health Promotion Board]] of Singapore launched the Healthy Eating in Schools Programme, which gives an award to schools which serve healthy meals. To receive the award, schools must reduce the sugar content in drinks and desserts, serve fewer deep-fried and fatty foods, and include two servings of greens in their meals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hpb.gov.sg/HOPPortal/programmes-article/3088|title=Healthy Meals in Schools Programme|date=3 March 2016|website=Health Promotion Board|publisher=Government of Singapore |access-date=21 May 2016}}</ref>
===South Korea=== [[File:A South Korean school lunch.jpg|thumb|A South Korean school lunch]]
School lunches in [[South Korea]] include [[South Korean cuisine|traditional foods]] like rice and [[kimchi]] ([[fermented]] cabbage).<ref name=huffingtonpost.com /> Other dishes may include [[sesame]] leaves stuffed with rice and covered with honey sauce; pumpkin potato soup; pancakes made of egg batter and green onions, with optional peppers and octopus; and cucumber-and-carrot salads.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/09/school-lunches-from-aroun_n_2100142.html#slide=1739858 | work=Huffington Post | first=Emmeline | last=Zhao | title=What School Lunches Look Like Around The World | date=9 November 2012}}</ref>
In most schools, the students set and hand out the various dishes, and then clean them up.
=== United Arab Emirates === {{Off topic|date=September 2018}}
Due to the economic boom, obesity has developed into a known health concern amongst adolescents in the [[United Arab Emirates]]. The past three decades have seen the largest increases in child obesity. Studies have shown that rates of obesity among the UAE's schoolchildren have surpassed the child obesity rates in both the United States and Europe. Traditional cuisine in the [[Persian Gulf]] region, once high-fibre and low-fat, has become Westernized, and now consists of many more high-fat, high-sodium, and high-cholesterol foods. Exercise levels among children have also decreased rapidly, causing the surge of obesity in adolescents.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bin Zaal|first1=A.A.| last2=Musaiger |first2=A.O. |last3=D'Souza |first3=R. |title=Dietary habits associated with obesity among adolescents in Dubai, United Arab Emirates|journal=Nutrición Hospitalaria|date=2009 |volume=24 |issue=4 |pages=437{{ndash}}444 |url=http://scielo.isciii.es/pdf/nh/v24n4/original1.pdf|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
==North America== ===Canada=== [[File:Children. Montreal High School BAnQ Vieux-Montréal P48S1P08746.jpg|thumbnail|Children eating their lunch in a Montreal school, 1943]] Canada has no national school meal program,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.breakfastforlearning.ca/en/how-to-help/canadas-children-need-a-national-nutrition-program |title=Canada's Children Need a National Nutrition Program |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205140422/http://www.breakfastforlearning.ca/en/how-to-help/canadas-children-need-a-national-nutrition-program |archivedate=5 February 2012 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2012 |website= |publisher=Breakfast for Learning |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref> and elementary schools are usually not equipped with kitchen facilities. Parents are generally expected to provide a [[packed lunch]] for their children to take to school, or have their children return home to eat during the lunch period. However, some [[non-profit organization]]s dedicated to student nutrition programs do exist.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.breakfastforlearning.ca/programs/ |title=Funded Programs |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= |publisher=Breakfast for Learning |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
Most Canadian middle schools (grades 6-8) and high schools (grades 9-12) have cafeterias that serve hot meals.
===United States=== {{Main|School meal programs in the United States}} {{See also|Childhood obesity in the United States}}
[[Image:School Lunch Programs.gif|thumb|Recipient of the U.S. School Lunch Program in 1936]]
====History==== School lunches at the national level began as a temporary [[New Deal]] project in 1933. By 1935 it was run by the [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] in 1935-42, as a way to employ the unemployed, feed hungry children, and reduce crop surpluses. It was ended in World War II when the WPA closed. In 1937 the WPA reported, "In the past year and a half 80,000,000 hot well-balanced meals have been served at the rate of 500,000 daily in 10,000 schools throughout the country."<ref>Ellen S. Woodward, "Hot Lunches for a Million School Children" [https://socialwelfare.library.vcu.edu/eras/great-depression/hot-lunches-million-school-children/ online]</ref>
The permanent [[National School Lunch Program]] was created in 1946, with the [[National School Lunch Act]].<ref name=usda>{{cite web |url=http://www.fns.usda.gov/sites/default/files/NSLPFactSheet.pdf |title=National School Lunch Program |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=September 2013 |website=Food and Nutrition Service |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160519052317/http://www.fns.usda.gov/sites/default/files/NSLPFactSheet.pdf |archivedate=19 May 2016 |df= }}</ref> This legislation won rural support because it removed surplus food from the market and thus raised prices paid to farmers.<ref>{{cite book|last=Poppendieck|first=Janet|title=Free For All: Fixing School Food in America|year=2010|publisher=[[University of California, Berkeley]]|isbn=0520269888}}</ref> Congress intended these meals to promote and protect child nutrition, while also supporting the consumption of American farm products.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ziperstein|first=Robyn|title=School Food, Inc.: The Contracting of America's National School Lunch Program and its Nutritional Consequences|journal=The Cornell Policy Review|date=3 March 2013|url=http://blogs.cornell.edu/policyreview/2012/03/15/school-food-inc-the-contracting-of-america’s-national-school-lunch-program-and-its-nutritional-consequences/| publisher=Cornell University Institute for Public Affairs |accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
====Current status==== Today, the National School Lunch Program is a federal nutrition assistance program operating in over 101,000 public schools, non-profit private schools, and residential care institutions. It is regulated and administered [[Federal government of the United States|at the federal level]] by the [[Food and Nutrition Service]] of the [[United States Department of Agriculture]] (USDA). The program provides "nutritionally balanced meals" at low or no cost to more than 31 million children each school day.<ref name=usda/>
Since its inception, the Program has expanded substantially. It now includes the [[School Breakfast Program]], the Snack Program, a [[Child and Adult Care Food Program]], and the [[Summer Food Service Program]]. At the State level, the National School Lunch Program is usually administered by state education agencies, which operate the program through agreements with school food authorities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fns.usda.gov/programs-and-services |title=Programs and Services |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=26 March 2014 |website=Food and Nutrition Service |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
School meal programs in the United States provide meals free of charge, or at a reduced (government-subsidized) price, to the children of low-income families. Those who do not qualify for free or reduced price are charged a nominal fee.<ref name=usda/>
Generally, private schools cannot participate in the school lunch program. Public or nonprofit private residential [[child care]] institutions may or may not participate. School districts and [[independent school]]s that choose to take part in the program get minimal cash subsidies and donated commodities from the USDA for each meal they serve. In return, they must serve lunches that meet federal requirements, and they must offer free or reduced-price lunches to eligible children. School food authorities can also be reimbursed for snacks served to children through age 18 in after-school education or enrichment programs.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
====Controversy==== There is some controversy over the fact that the USDA is simultaneously responsible for promoting health through nutritious school meals and diet guidelines, and for promoting the consumption of major agricultural products such as dairy and pork.<ref>{{cite news|last=Moss|first=Michael|title=While Warning About Fat, U.S. Pushes Cheese Sales|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/07/us/07fat.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0| date=6 November 2010 |accessdate=21 May 2016 |newspaper=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company}}</ref> Critics say this is an innate [[conflict of interest]], evident in the degree to which setting the National School Lunch Program standards remains a political process, influenced to a degree by food industry [[lobbying|lobbyists]]. These critics argue that school meals' nutritional standards do not include some of the basics needed for a healthy diet, as established by nutrition science.<ref>{{cite web|title=Healthy Eating Plate vs. USDA's MyPlate|url=http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/healthy-eating-plate-vs-usda-myplate/|work=Nutrition Source|publisher=Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
Other controversy stems from students individual needs and the increase in food allergies <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.revealnews.org/article/open-campus-policy-eats-away-at-school-nutrition-effort.|title=Open-campus policy eats away at school nutrition effort|date=2013-05-09|work=Reveal|access-date=2017-12-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
====Contents and nutritional guidelines==== School lunches must meet the applicable recommendations of the [[Dietary Guidelines for Americans]]. These guidelines state that no more than 30 percent of an individual's calories should come from fat, and less than 10 percent from [[saturated fat]]. Regulations also state that school lunches must provide one-third of the [[Recommended Dietary Allowance]]s of protein, [[Vitamin A]], [[Vitamin C]], [[iron]], [[calcium]], and calories. School lunches must meet federal nutrition requirements over the course of one week's worth of lunches. However, local school food authorities may make decisions about which specific foods to serve and how they are prepared.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
Vending machines in schools are also a major source of competitive food for students. Under pressure from parents and anti-obesity advocates, many school districts moved to ban [[soft drink|sodas]], junk foods, and candy from vending machines and cafeterias.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Otto, Mary |author2=Aratani, Lori |last-author-amp=yes |title=Soda Ban Means Change at Schools: Policy Bolsters Regional Systems That Already Limited Sales |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/03/AR2006050302399_pf.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |location= |date=4 May 2006 |accessdate=21 May 2016 }}</ref> Various laws have also been passed to limit foods sold in school vending machines. With increasing concern over traditional vending machines in schools, healthier vending options have gained popularity and are steadily being adopted by schools around the nation.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--CBS News Staff--> |title=School vending machine laws would help kids lose weight, study shows |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/school-vending-machine-laws-would-help-kids-lose-weight-study-shows/ |newspaper=CBS News |location= |date=13 August 2012 |accessdate=21 May 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.grbj.com/articles/75826-healthier-snacks-from-smarter-machines |title=Healthier snacks from smarter machines: Young entrepreneur studied vending machine management at MSU |author=Daly, Pete |date=29 December 2012 |website=Grand Rapids Business Journal Online |publisher=Gemini Publications |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref> Marketing for such "healthy vending machines" states that they allow students to perform better in school while also attaining better health.
==Africa== ===Nigeria=== In April 2012, the [[Osun (state)|State of Osun]] in [[Nigeria]] pioneered a statewide school meals programme for all public elementary school pupils. It is called the O'Meals programme (an [[acronym]] for the Osun Elementary School Feeding and Health Programme). As of July 2014, it was providing lunch to over 252,000 children in 100% of Osun's elementary schools. In addition to [[Nigerian cuisine|staples]] such as rice, beans, and yams served with stews, soups, and vegetables, the programme provides daily fruits. Its estimated cost is [[Nigerian dollar|N]]50 (USD $0.31) per child per day.<ref name=omeals>{{cite web |url=http://hgsf-global.org/en/bank/downloads/doc_download/433-omeals-snap-shot-july-2014 |title=O’Meals {{ndash}} Why It’s More Than Just Lunch |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=July 2014 |website=HGSF Nigeria |publisher=Home Grown School Feeding (HGSF) |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
According to a report on O'Meals' benefits:<ref name=omeals/>
{{cquote|Within four weeks of the O'Meals launch, school enrollment increase[d] by approximately 25%. According to the Nigerian National Bureau of Statistics July 2013 edition, Osun has the highest primary school enrollment rates in Nigeria {{ndash}} a feat largely attributable to O'Meals. [Additionally,] O'Meals promotes and boosts income generation opportunities, particularly for women. To date, the program has economically empowered over 3,000 previously unemployed women by hiring them as food vendors[.]}}
All food items are sourced locally from farmers and others on the supply chain, enhancing employment within the state. Addressing child malnutrition has raised students' academic performance, and has increased school enrollment by 24% compared to figures from before April 2012.<ref>{{cite book|last1=McGrath |first1=Simon |last2=Gu |first2=Qing |title=Routledge Handbook of International Education and Development|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0415747547|page=174}}</ref>
In 2015, the [[manifesto]] of the [[All Progressives Congress]] (APC) advocated for the adoption of a nationwide free meal plan. Since he became [[President of Nigeria|President]], [[Muhammadu Buhari]] has made the implementation of this policy one of his foremost priorities. A national School Meals programme is the subject of a budgetary proposal before the [[National Assembly of Nigeria|National Assembly]]. Also, the government of [[Kaduna State]] has implemented a school feeding programme.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
==Australia== ===Healthy Kids Association === {{See also|Childhood obesity in Australia}} The Healthy Kids Association (previously The Healthy Kids School Canteen Association) is a not-for-profit, non-governmental, health promotion organization based in [[Sydney, Australia]].<ref name=FV>{{cite report |url=http://www.vichealth.vic.gov.au/~/media/ResourceCentre/PublicationsandResources/healthy%20eating/FruitVegConsumptionWaste.ashx|page=38|title=Fruit and Vegetable Consumption and Waste in Australia|author=Morgan, Emily|publisher=VicHealth: Victorian Health Promotion Foundation, State Government of Victoria |date=March 2009 |accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> It is a [[peak organisation]] for school canteens in [[New South Wales]] and the [[Australian Capital Territory]] (ACT).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-15/canberra-school-canteen-overhaul-proves-a-success/6547774|title=Canberra school canteen overhaul proves a success, P&C encourages others to follow suit|work=ABC News Australia |date=15 June 2015 |accessdate=21 May 2016 |author=Cornish, Ruby}}</ref>
In [[Australia]], many school canteens have returned to offering [[junk food]], or pupils have started buying [[fast food]] outside their schools. The association has developed policies intended to counter these trends; in some schools, they have taken over providing school food.<ref name="NewsComAu 2015">{{cite news | title=Health nazis losing obesity war as pies return to school canteens | work=The Daily Telegraph |location=Surry Hills, New South Wales |publisher=News Corp | date=15 June 2009 | url=http://www.news.com.au/national/health-nazis-losing-obesity-war-as-pies-return-to-school-canteens/story-e6frfkp9-1225734745940 | accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
In response to the 2002 Childhood Obesity Summit, former [[Premiers of New South Wales|Premier of New South Wales]] [[Bob Carr]] launched the "Fresh Tastes NSW Healthy School Canteen Strategy." Healthy Kids has become a key partner of the [[Australian Ministry of Health|Ministry of Health]] in developing this plan. The strategy is to develop a taste for healthier foods among schoolchildren by promoting and featuring healthier menu options, while limiting the availability of less nutritious foods.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/obesity/adult/canteens.html |title= Childhood Obesity: Healthy School Canteens |accessdate= 21 May 2016 |date= 15 July 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719183407/http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/obesity/adult/canteens.html |archivedate=19 July 2008 |website=NSW Health |publisher=NSW Government}}</ref> The program's menu guide was partially created by [[Rosemary Stanton]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Browne, Rachel |title=Fat lot of good done by healthy canteen rules |url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/diet-and-fitness/fat-lot-of-good-done-by-healthy-canteen-rules-20100918-15h4g.html |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney, Australia |date=19 September 2010 |accessdate=21 May 2016 |publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref>

{{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=Shelley v. Kraemer |ArgueDate=January 14 |ArgueYear=1948 |DecideDate=May 3 |DecideYear=1948 |FullName=Shelley et ux. v. Kraemer et ux. McGhee et ux. v. Sipes et al. |USVol=334 |USPage=1 |ParallelCitations=68 S. Ct. 836; 92 [[L. Ed.]] 1161; 3 [[A.L.R.2d]] 441 |Prior=Judgment for defendants; reversed, 198 [[S.W.2d]] 679 (Mo. 1947); certiorari granted. Judgment for plaintiffs; affirmed 25 [[N.W.2d]] 638 (Mich. 614); certiorari granted. |Subsequent= |Holding=The Fourteenth Amendment prohibits a state from enforcing restrictive covenants that would prohibit a person from owning or occupying property based on race or color. |SCOTUS=1946-1949 |Majority=Vinson |JoinMajority=Black, Frankfurter, Douglas, Murphy, Burton |NotParticipating=Reed, Jackson and Rutledge |LawsApplied=[[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|U.S. Const. amend. XIV]] }} '''''Shelley v. Kraemer''''', 334 U.S. 1 (1948), is a [[List of landmark court decisions in the United States|landmark]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/civilrights/mo1.htm |publisher=[[National Park Service]] |work=We Shall Overcome: Historic Places of the Civil Rights Movement |title=Shelley House |accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> [[United States Supreme Court]] case holding that the [[State actor|State-Action Doctrine]] includes the enforcement of private contracts, the [[Equal Protection Clause]] prohibits racially restrictive housing [[Covenant (law)|covenants]], and that such covenants are unenforceable in court.
==Facts== In 1945, an African-American family by the name of Shelley purchased a [[Shelley House (St. Louis, Missouri)|house]] in [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]]. At the time of purchase, they were unaware that a [[restrictive covenant]] had been in place on the property since 1911. The restrictive covenant prevented "people of the [[Negro]] or [[Mongoloid|Mongolian]] Race" from occupying the property. Louis Kraemer, who lived ten blocks away, sued to prevent the Shelleys from gaining possession of the property. The [[Supreme Court of Missouri]] held that the covenant was enforceable against the purchasers because the covenant was a purely private agreement between its original parties. As such, it "ran with the land" and was enforceable against subsequent owners. Moreover, since it ran in favor of an estate rather than merely a person, it could be enforced against a third party. A materially similar scenario occurred in the [[companion case]] ''McGhee v. Sipes'' from [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], where the McGhees purchased land that was subject to a similar restrictive covenant. The Supreme Court consolidated both cases for oral arguments and considered two questions:
* Are racially based restrictive covenants legal under the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]] of the [[United States Constitution]]? * Can they be enforced by a court of law?
==Decision== The Supreme Court held "that the [racially] restrictive agreements, standing alone, cannot be regarded as violative of any rights guaranteed to petitioners by the Fourteenth Amendment."<ref>''Shelley v. Kraemer'', {{ussc|334|1|1948}}.</ref> Private parties may abide by the terms of such a restrictive covenant, but they may not seek judicial enforcement of such a covenant, as that would be a [[state actor|state action]]. Such state action would be discriminatory so the enforcement of a racially based restrictive covenant in a state court would violate the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the Fourteenth Amendment.
The court rejected the argument that since state courts would enforce a restrictive covenant against white people, judicial enforcement of restrictive covenants would not violate the Equal Protection Clause. The court noted that the Fourteenth Amendment guarantees individual rights, and that equal protection of the law is not achieved by the imposition of inequalities:
{{Quote|We have no doubt that there has been state action in these cases in the full and complete sense of the phrase. The undisputed facts disclose that petitioners were willing purchasers of properties upon which they desired to establish homes. The owners of the properties were willing sellers, and contracts of sale were accordingly consummated. It is clear that, but for the active intervention of the state courts, supported by the full panoply of state power, petitioners would have been free to occupy the properties in question without restraint.
These are not cases, as has been suggested, in which the States have merely abstained from action, leaving private individuals free to impose such discriminations as they see fit. Rather, these are cases in which the States have made available to such individuals the full coercive power of government to deny to petitioners, on the grounds of race or color, the enjoyment of property rights in premises which petitioners are willing and financially able to acquire and which the grantors are willing to sell. The difference between judicial enforcement and nonenforcement of the restrictive covenants is the difference to petitioners between being denied rights of property available to other members of the community and being accorded full enjoyment of those rights on an equal footing.}}
==Background== George L. Vaughn was a black attorney who represented J.D. Shelley at the Supreme Court of the United States. The attorneys who argued the case for the McGhees were [[Thurgood Marshall]] and [[Loren Miller (judge)|Loren Miller]]. The [[United States Solicitor General]], [[Philip Perlman]], who argued in this case that the restrictive covenants were unconstitutional, had previously in 1925 as the city solicitor of [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]] acted to support the city government's segregation efforts.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mitchell|first=Juanita Jackson|title=''Meade v. Dennistone'': The NAACP's Test Case to "... Sue Jim Crow Out of Maryland with the Fourteenth Amendment|journal=Maryland Law Review|volume=63|pages=807|year=2004|url= |doi=}}</ref>
''[[Hurd v. Hodge]]'' and ''Urciolo v. Hodge''<ref>{{ussc|334|24}}</ref> were companion cases from the [[District of Columbia]]. The Equal Protection Clause does not explicitly apply to a US territory not in a [[U.S. state]], but the Court found that both the [[Civil Rights Act of 1866]] and treating persons in the District of Columbia like those in the states forbade restrictive covenants.
==Recusals== Three justices -- Robert H. Jackson, Stanley Reed, and Wiley B. Rutledge -- recused themselves from the case because they owned property subject to restrictive covenants.
==Solicitor General's brief== The Solicitor General's brief filed on behalf of the United States government was written by four Jewish lawyers: [[Philip Elman]], [[Oscar Hirsh Davis|Oscar H. Davis]], [[Hilbert Philip Zarky|Hilbert P. Zarky]], and [[Stanley M. Silverberg]]. However, the Solicitor General’s office chose to omit their names from the brief. Deputy Solicitor General [[Arnold Raum]], who was also Jewish, stated that it was "bad enough that [Solicitor General Philip] [[Philip Perlman|Perlman]]’s name has to be there, to have one Jew’s name on it, but you have also put four more Jewish names on. That makes it look as if a bunch of Jewish lawyers in the Department of Justice put this out."<ref>{{cite journal |first=Philip |last=Elman |first2=Norman |last2=Silber |title=The Solicitor General's Office, Justice Frankfurter, and Civil Rights Litigation, 1946–1960: An Oral History |volume=100 |journal=[[Harvard Law Review]] |issue=4 |pages=817–852 [p. 819] |year=1987 |jstor=1341096 |doi=10.2307/1341096 }} As quoted in {{cite journal |authorlink=Seth Waxman |last=Waxman |first=Seth |title=Twins at Birth: Civil Rights and the Role of the Solicitor General |journal=Indiana Law Journal |volume=75 |issue= |pages=1297, 1306 n. 53}}</ref>
==Literary responses== In 2010, Jeffrey S. Copeland published ''Olivia's Story: The Conspiracy of Heroes Behind Shelley v. Kraemer'',<ref>Copeland, Jeffrey S. (2010) ''Olivia's Story: The Conspiracy of Heroes Behind Shelley v. Kraemer.'' Paragon House.</ref> a literary nonfiction account of events leading up to the Shelley v. Kraemer case. In 2017, a documentary film was made titled "The Story of Shelley v. Kraemer." The script for the film was written by Copeland, and it was produced by Joe Marchesani and Laney Kraus-Taddeo of the Audio/Video Production Services division of Educational Technology and Media Services at the [[University of Northern Iowa]] ([[Cedar Falls, Iowa]]).<ref>Parker, Melody. [http://wcfcourier.com/lifestyles/docu-drama-uni-prof-makes-film-about-landmark-civil-rights/article_d046dd21-c4c5-5794-8342-f73069647ea8.html "Docu-drama: UNI Prof Makes Film About Landmark Civil Rights Case."] Waterloo/Cedar Falls Courier. (1 April 2017).</ref> The film has been a featured part of the exhibit titled "#1 in Civil Rights: The African American Freedom Struggle in St. Louis,"<ref>Russell, Stefene. "At the Missouri History Museum, '[https://www.stlmag.com/history/at-the-missouri-history-museum-1-in-civil-rights-corrects-the-record/ #1 in Civil Rights' Corrects the Record]." ''Missouri History Museum Newsletter''. (20 July 2017).</ref> at the [[Missouri History Museum]] in [[St. Louis]]. The film was also nominated for the [[Sundance Film Festival]].

Warley]]'' (1917), a Supreme Court of the United States case which overturned racial zoning ordinances *''[[Corrigan v. Buckley]]'' (1926), a Supreme Court of the United States case which upheld racially restrictive covenants *''[[Hansberry v. Lee]]'' (1940), a Supreme Court of the United States case which allowed renewed challenges to racial covenants *''[[Noble v. Alley]]'', a similar case decided by the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] in 1951
